title: 115_hr1728
content: Boundary modification for Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area in Idaho. Definitions for the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area include terms like Conservation Area, Gateway West, Map, Sage-grouse species, and Secretary. The boundary of the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of a settlement agreement are met. The BLM Jarbidge Field Office will manage Creek Allotment lands until terms of a settlement agreement are met, after which management will transfer to the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area office. Approximately 86 acres of BOR Administered Lands will be included, while 761 acres of Segment 8 Revised Proposed Route will be excluded. The Gateway West Transmission Line will be sited within 500 feet of the existing Summer Lake Transmission Line. Approximately 1,845 acres of land are designated for the Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route. The right-of-way must be established within 90 days of the enactment of the law. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines within 90 days of the law's enactment. The right-of-way will align with revised proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines within 90 days of the law's enactment. The conditions for the right-of-way include mitigation measures during construction in accordance with the Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement framework. Gateway West will contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area during construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route, totaling 761 acres and 1,845 acres respectively, to the Bureau of Land Management Foundation for conservation purposes. The Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement costs are capped at $8,543,440. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will receive 1,845 acres from Gateway West for conservation purposes in Idaho. Gateway West will cover all associated costs, and the Secretary will administer the lands as part of the Conservation Area according to the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Secretary will administer the lands as part of the Conservation Area in accordance with Public Law 103-64 and the National Landscape Conservation System. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. A map showing the lands will be available for public inspection. The map showing the transferred lands will be available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management offices. Within 18 months, the Secretary will amend the management plan for the Conservation Area to address long-term management activities and grazing of livestock on the lands described in subsection (b)(1). The law allows for continued grazing, motorized access, hunting, and fishing on specified lands, subject to reasonable regulations set by the Secretary. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation with similar authorities to the National Park Foundation. The Foundation aims to address specific challenges such as reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, and expanded scientific understanding. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will focus on reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, expanded scientific understanding of development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and identification of cultural and historical treasures on public lands.
